characters: PARTS OF THE ROOM FADE AWAY. THE UNIMPORTANT PARTS TO
DOORS TO THE VANS AND SUVS OPEN
I'M WALKING OUT OF HERE NOW
THE LARGE MAN FILLS THE DOOR FRAME
HE WAS IN MY FUCKING HOUSE
JUST AS THE WINDOWS EXPLODE IN A SHOWER OF GLASS
DOORS TO A MIDTOWN BUS OPEN
ITS WAY AROUND HIS GUN HAND. COVERING HIS FINGER ON THE
SUBWAY CAR KILLING THEM INSTANTLY AS IT ROARS BY...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blender being loaded: Wheat grass, Almond milk, Whey protein, a cup of organic Blueberries. WRIST WATCH - finger hits the stopwatch button on it...

dialogues.speaker: HANDS DO THE DISHES
dialogues.text: Drying the blender and glass. Into a cabinet where there' only ONE of everything.

dialogues.speaker: ARMS IRON A SHIRT
dialogues.text: With the precision of a surgeon. Spray starch, stiff coll and cuffs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shirt’s buttoned. Leather belt slipped into creased pants Tie knotted and tightened exactly. Stepping in front of a mirror...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Middle aged, middle class, middle of the road looks. Plea with his appearance, McCall adds a final touch. An ORANGE VEST. Finger hits the STOP button on the watch timer...

dialogues.speaker: A DOZEN ORANGE VESTS
dialogues.text: Moving about various aisles inside...

dialogues.speaker: HOME DEPOT
dialogues.text: Dollies full of Quickset, painting materials and plumbing supplies being wheeled through the aisles by CONTRACTORS HANDYMEN. McCall on a ladder tossing down a box of wall switches to DAY LABORER.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Didn't you pick up switches last week?

dialogues.speaker: LABORER
dialogues.text: Owner wants touch dimmers now. McCall smiles. Climbs down the ladder.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: When they pay...

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL/LABORER
dialogues.text: They say.

dialogues.speaker: LOADING DOCK
dialogues.text: McCall PUSHES a dolly LOADED WITH PLYWOOD towards a panel VAN. Huffing and puffing past TWO YOUNG DUDES leaning against a fork lift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should make the old guys take fitness tests.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG DUDE 2
dialogues.text: Like Firemen. McCall sweating. Removing his gloves as he walks past the Young Dudes.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG DUDE 1
dialogues.text: Betcha didn’t have to push no dolly in your last job, did ya Pops.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: (good natured) Guilty as charged. As he walks off...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG GUY 2
dialogues.text: Dudes come in here thinkin’ it’s all tape measures, paint cans and “how may I help you”.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCall on his break. A DOZEN EMPLOYEES scattered around t room on plastic chairs in front of Formica tables. McCall makes his way to the back table where RALPHIE, a heavyset kid in his 20's sits alone. Takes a seat. Ralphie empties the contents of his bag for McCall to see McCall looks suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: RALPHIE
dialogues.text: It’s Tuna.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: What kind of bread?

dialogues.speaker: RALPHIE
dialogues.text: Whole grain. Gluten-free.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Condiments?

dialogues.speaker: RALPHIE
dialogues.text: Sprouts. Avocado. Veganese Mayo. McCall smiles. Digs into his ground turkey and veggie mi Ralphie bites into his sandwich...

dialogues.speaker: CRUNCH
dialogues.text: Ralphie winces. On McCall’s look Ralphie slides his sandw across the table. McCall lifts the bread to reveal a laye of potato chips.

dialogues.speaker: RALPHIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What? Potatoes are a vegetable. Prison yard stare from McCall.

dialogues.speaker: RALPHIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I like crunchy things.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Carrots are crunchy. Dried seaweed is crunchy. You like those? McCall picks off a chip, holds it up.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Partially hydrogenated vegetable oil. Corn syrup. Those are the enemy, son. (beat) You wanna make Security Guard? You gotta lose weight. Test is coming up in a week. You asked me to help you. But if you’re not going to apply yourself... Ralphie drops his head in defeat. McCall reaches across t table and lifts Ralphie’s head back up.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey. You can do it. Progress, not perfection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rush hour crowded. McCall stands in the packed car. Just another tired face at the end of a long day...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lower middle class neighborhood of aging apartment buildi and bodegas. Street lamps flicker on as McCall reaches a five story wa up.

dialogues.speaker: BUILDING FOYER
dialogues.text: McCall opens the only mailbox with no name on it. Removes flyer and a credit card offer that go right in the trash.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL'S KITCHEN
dialogues.text: McCall watching the 6:30 news as he washes his dinner dishes... Single dish, fork, knife and glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only half operational. Ferris Wheel moans and creaks unde the weight of bundled up PATRONS. McCall sits on a bench PEOPLE watching. Comfortable. At peace. PING! The SHOOTING BOOTH catches his attention. Watches a poor IMMIGRANT FATHER plop down dollar after dollar valia trying to win a giant Sponge Bob for his kid. Only to fail every time. The Father eventually runs out of dollars and walks off w his heartbroken son. INT. MCCALL’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Clock reads 9:40. McCall in bed. Reading a hardcover of Hemingway's “Old man and the Sea”.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the dark. Wide awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A punch-drunk, open-all-night dive. A bored COUNTERMAN behind the chipped Formica counter. DOORMAN from down the block reads the next days paper. A lone GIRL at a table by the window, ear phones in, iPod playing, eyes closed... Cheap cocktail dress, stockings a costume jewelry leave no doubt what she is... Wall clock says 2:11 AM when McCall walks in with his boo Shuffles to a seat at his usual table near the back. Counterman comes over and sets a cup and a small pot of h water at McCall’s table without asking. McCall uses a napkin to wipe out the cup. Takes a tea bag from his pock drops it in the cup and pours the boiling water over it. Opens his book and reads.

dialogues.speaker: TERI, (OS)
dialogues.text: He catch the fish yet? McCall glances up. Teri THE HOOKER pulling her earphones out. Pretty, late 20s. Few tats peeking out from her dres

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Just hooked it.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: About time.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: It’s a big fish. Don’t know if he can hang on to it though.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: (playful) Oh no.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Tooth and nail right now.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: Maybe he’s too old. McCall nods. They’re quiet for a while. Teri takes a bit of her Apple pie.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Thought you were going to stop eating all that refined sugar.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: (with a mouthful) I am.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: When.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: Any day now.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Bad for the vocal cords. Teri looks away sheepishly.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How’s the singing? She shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: Got myself a little machine to make demos. We’ll see.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Bet you’re good.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: What makes you think that?

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Intuition. Teri smiles her first real smile. After a beat they desce back into silence. Teri finishes her pie. Shoulders her tote and starts for door.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: Lemme know what happens next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCall rolls another Dolly past the Young Dudes slacking INT. HOME DEPOT —- HARDWARE AISLE —- MORNING Ralphie stocking packages of extension cords. Looks aroun to make sure no one is looking... Pushes aside some boxes and reaches his arm to the back o the shelf. Pulls out... A bag of sunflower seeds?

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL, (OS)
dialogues.text: Crunchy. Just how you like ‘em. Ralphie looks up to see McCall walk off holding the Snick Bar he was looking for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCall on his break. Popping sunflower seeds and watching the trucks being loaded. Looks up to see the two Young Dudes standing over him.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG DUDE 1
dialogues.text: We're bettin’ on what you did ‘fore you got here?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG DUDE 2
dialogues.text: For a living. YOUNG DUDE 2 (CONT’D) I bet Insurance. Claims and shit.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG DUDE 1
dialogues.text: Wall Street. Stock dude. McCall pockets his seeds.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: I was a Pip.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG DUDE 1
dialogues.text: Pip? The fuck is a Pip?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know. Gladys Knight and the Pips? McCall gets up. Does a little Pip move. Pulling the whist on the Midnight Train to Georgia. Young Dudes eyes wideni as they slowly get it.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG DUDE 2
dialogues.text: No shit!

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: One on the right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCall collects his paycheck from the SUPERVISOR.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CHECK CASHING PLACE
dialogues.text: McCall stands in line with OTHER WORKERS. FACES in line not much different from his. Men not where they expected to be at this stage in life. INT. MCCALL’S APARTMENT Dinner dishes already cleaned and put away. McCall’s at his book case in the back hallway. Watering t few small plants that live on top of it. Shelves lined wi book titles that seem eclectic...

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Work clothes laid out. Bed empty. Clock reads 2:18 AM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCall at his table reading a new book. Tea bag floating his cup. Doorman at the counter with the Post as Teri glides in an plops down in her usual spot.  10. Counterman already over with her coffee and donut. Teri takes a quick bite and a sip. Turns to McCall.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: He catch the fish?

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: He did.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: Happy ending. Yay.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Not exactly. McCall closes his book.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Old Man tied the dead fish to the boat and had to row back... Teri’s elbows on the table now.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: On the way in the fish bled out into the water. Blood drew sharks. The old man tried to fight them off... (beat) Ate the fish before he could get it home.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: So the whole thing was a waste.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Depends on how you look at it. (beat) Old Man spent his life fighting fish. Then, when he figured that part of his life was over, he met his greatest adversary. (beat) It was as if both of them had been waiting for this moment. (beat) During the struggle the Old Man sort of formed a bond - a respect - for the fish. A kind of love.  11.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: Why didn’t he let it go then?

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: The Old Man had to be the old man and the Fish had to be the fish. That's life. You gotta be who you are. A long pause. Two people who understand loss.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: Well. He lost.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Old man went out too far. Farther than he should have. A long silence. Teri breathes into her cup so the soft st touches her face. Counterman rhythmically wipes the count McCall picks up his new book. Outside, it begins to rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCall sitting with Ralphie going over his food plan when SEVERAL EMPLOYEES singing “Happy Birthday” enter the room SUPERVISOR GEORGIE holds a donut sporting a lit candle. McCall reacts with confusion as Georgie puts the donut in front of him. Georgie laughs at McCall’s blank look.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: You forget? McCall realizes it’s for HIS birthday. Shaking his head..

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Talk about a senior moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teri at her table. Ear phones in. Lost in some song when donut is placed in front of her. Looks up to see McCall.  12.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Loaded with poison... Just the way you like it. A beat, she looks up at him. Ugly bruise on her face. McCall pretends not to notice.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Someone's birthday at work. Didn’t want to waste it. Goes to his table and sits. Counterman brings the pot and cup. McCall takes out his tea bag. Teri walks over with the donut and sits. Slides a burned over to him.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: Let me know if I’m any good. Catches McCall sneaking a look at her bruise.

dialogues.speaker: TERI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You should see the other guy. It’s okay... Comes with the job. Picks up the donut.

dialogues.speaker: TERI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whose birthday?

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Some guy.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: Happy birthday, some guy. (a beat) I'm breaking protocol. Should I go back to my table?

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: No. It’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: I just needed company tonight. (beat) Teri.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Bob.  13. Teri studies McCall.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: You don’t look like a Bob. More like a Robert. Robert reads books. Bob watches TV. McCall smiles. Picks up the CD.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Teri the singer.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: You and I both know what I really am. Takes a bite of the donut.

dialogues.speaker: TERI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean I WANT to be a singer. I THINK I can be a singer. Doesn't make me one.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: I believe anybody can be who they want to be. Teri laughs.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: Maybe where you come from. Not in my world.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Then change your world.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: Not that easy. Comfortable silence.

dialogues.speaker: TERI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No ring. (off McCall’s look) On your finger. No Mrs. Robert at home?

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: Ever?

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Once. A ways back.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: Break her heart?

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: She broke mine. (beat) She died. Teri looks at McCall with a mixture of sadness and curios

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: Thought that might be it. I seea lot of widowed guys. It’s the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: The eyes.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: Yeah. Not sad. Just... lost. It's sweet. McCall doesn’t blink. Smart girl.

dialogues.speaker: TERI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You always read?

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: No. My wife did. I was away a lot. For work. So she read. Was making her way through the 100 Books everyone should read. Got to 97. (beat) Figured it would give us something to talk about someday. Something we could share.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: A hundred books... Holy moly. How many have you read?

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: No shit. 91. Almost done.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Almost. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: Then what?

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCall and Teri walk out together.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: I’m gonna grab a cab. Both head for the corner...

dialogues.speaker: TERI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s 92 about? McCall holds up DON QUIXOTE.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Guy who thinks he’s a Knight. Only he lives in a world where knights don't exist any more.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: Sounds like my world. Teri steps to the curb to hail a cab. A Few FLY BY. Then WHITE VAN rolls up. TALL MAN with LONG HAIR gets out of the passenger side. B colored leather jacket, tanning-bed complexion. McCall watches Teri stiffen. The two ARGUE in Russian. Finally Teri looks back at him.

dialogues.speaker: TERI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have to go with them. It’s okay. See you... when I see you.  16. Forces a smile and gets in the van. Tall Guy walks over t McCall. Hands him a card.

dialogues.speaker: SLAVI
dialogues.text: (Russian accent) You call number... they send you another one. Just as good. Tell them Slavi said. Gets back in the Van and drives off. McCall turns the car over in his hand. An escort service.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bathed in SHADOWS. Everything still. Just the SOUND of Teri’s CD wafting through the rooms. McCall at the kitchen table with a glass of Grapefruit ju Listening. Rough, edgy, passionate, unpolished. A diamond in the rou McCall’s eyes twinkle just a tad. Not bad...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PEARL, 300 pounds of attitude, walking towards the BACK OFFICE. The Two Young Dudes sidle up on either side of he

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG DUDE 2
dialogues.text: Pearly. Which one of us you gonna ask out.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG DUDE 1
dialogues.text: Seen you eyeing us for a week now. But you can only have one of us so... Whose it gonna be?

dialogues.speaker: PEARL
dialogues.text: Been eyein’ you two, alright. Young Dudes primping now.  17.

dialogues.speaker: PEARL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Trying to figure out what either one of you lazy mutherfuckers do all day and why I shouldn’t fire your worthless, bony asses. Dudes stopping, letting Pearl continue on.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG DUDE 2
dialogues.text: Seems more like your type... Dude 1 SEES McCall handing a DRIVER a receipt at the LOAD DOCK. Stepping into his path.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG DUDE 1
dialogues.text: Yo. You weren’t no Pip, Old Man. Shoves his iPhone under his nose. You Tube Video of Glady Knight and the Pips. McCall smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Soul Train. ‘82. That’s me. On the end.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG DUDE 2
dialogues.text: Ain’t you.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Few pounds lighter and a lot more hair. But damn. I was good looking. McCall perfectly mirrors the dance moves then walks off leaving the Young Dudes staring at the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCall at his table. Tea poured. DON QUIXOTE open in fron of him. Keeps glancing at the door. No Teri tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several LUNCH TRUCKS parked out front. Orange Vests sprinkled out, eating under trees or on the grass. Not McCall or Ralphie.  18. They're at the far edge of the lot, McCall putting Ralphi through an exercise routine. Urging him to do one more pu up, one more push up.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Who’s gonna be the best Security Guard?

dialogues.speaker: RALPHIE
dialogues.text: I am, SIR!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCall walks in. Again, no Teri. The Counterman brings ov his cup and pot of hot water. Notices McCall eyeing the door.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTERMAN
dialogues.text: She's up at Kings County. Heard someone beat her up pretty bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCall is standing on one side of a chicken wire and glas window staring into the Intensive Care room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight beds. All filled. Teri’s in the far corner. Attached to wires and IV's. Face bandaged, neck in a brac Almost unrecognizable. A YOUNG WOMAN dozes in a chair next to the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same Young Woman pays for a cup of coffee. Takes it t a condiment station and loads it with an ungodly amount o sugar.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL, (OS)
dialogues.text: How's she doing? Her head snaps. Finds McCall sitting at a far table.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Teri. How’s she doing?  19. The Young Woman eyes McCall, hard as rock. Just another John...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: Well she’s not good. The Young Woman reaches for her coffee and tries to bring cup to her lips. Hands begin shaking and the coffee spill McCall steps over and takes the cup from her hands. Sets down then gets some napkins and sops up the spillage.

dialogues.speaker: THE CAFETERIA
dialogues.text: Under the green glow of Fluorescents, McCall sits at the Young Woman’s table listening.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: «+. guy hit her. Some Johns think they can do that. (beat) She hit him back and the guy called Slavi...

dialogues.speaker: WHAM
dialogues.text: TERI’S FACE (FLASHBACK) Hit with a massive fist. Cheek bone shattering.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN, (OS)
dialogues.text: He set her straight...

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS OFFICE
dialogues.text: Teri face up on the carpet. A RING OF MEN standing over h On the couch THREE OTHER ESCORTS (including the Young Wom sit silently in horror.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN, (OS)
dialogues.text: They like making examples of trouble makers. Slavi rubs his fist. Offers Teri his hand and gently help her up. Teri tries to speak but Slavi flicks open a knife and pre it to her throat.  20.

dialogues.speaker: SLAVI
dialogues.text: No talking. Talking is not problem. Listening is problem. Presses harder. Opens a small cut in her throat. Teri GROANS. Uses the knife to push Teri to her knees in. Other hand unzips his pants and forces himself into her mouth. Slavi uses the knife to control Teri’s head. Boris moves behind Teri. Rips her pants open and violentl enters her from behind. The rest stare glassy-eyed as Sla and Boris rape Teri.

dialogues.speaker: HOSPITAL CAFETERIA
dialogues.text: The Young Woman stares out into the empty room. Numb to t brutality.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: Said they’d cut her throat next time. (beat) Said a whore who fucks and can’t talk is worth twice as much...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCall rides home on an almost empty car. Rocks with the rhythm of the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That White VAN pulls up to the Valet outside an AFTER HOU CLUB. The Driver, BORIS, steps out and enters a street le door...

dialogues.speaker: MAIN DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: Boris moves through the packed DINING ROOM to a...

dialogues.speaker: BACK STAIRWELL
dialogues.text: Where he jogs up to an second floor door.  21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THREE prison-hard THUGS sprawled on the couch watching th TV. Boris waddles in and plops down in front of Slavi who sit behind a large desk. Tosses an envelope onto the desk. Slavi drops the envelope on an antique scale - sees it’s correct - and slides it into the top drawer. Pours a shot for Boris... When the DOOR OPENS and Robert McCall steps inside...

dialogues.speaker: OFFICE
dialogues.text: Heads turn. Russians eyeballing up McCall like lions do Antelope.

dialogues.speaker: SLAVI
dialogues.text: You lost, dedushka? McCall hesitates. Makes his way to the desk. Places the card Slavi gave him in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: You gave me this the other night.

dialogues.speaker: SLAVI
dialogues.text: I give out lots of cards. You want pussy, dedushka? You still get it up? Chuckles from everybody. McCall waits for it to stop.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: I’m here about a certain girl. Slavi waits.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Name’s Teri. She was beat up pretty bad. The room gets quiet.

dialogues.speaker: SLAVI
dialogues.text: I think you have the wrong address, dedushka.  22.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: I’m not a cop or anything. I just want to help her. Slavi studies the man in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These girls. They represent an investment to you. I understand that. McCall glances around at the other guys.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can give you four thousand eight hundred dollars. It’s all I have.

dialogues.speaker: SLAVI
dialogues.text: You want to give me four thousand dollars. For what?

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Her freedom. Slavi looks at McCall. Another heartsick John...

dialogues.speaker: SLAVI
dialogues.text: This whore. What’s her name again?

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Teri.

dialogues.speaker: SLAVI
dialogues.text: (pretending to think) Doesn't ring a bell. Whoever she is she must really know how to suck cock. The muscle LAUGH.

dialogues.speaker: SLAVI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Believe this guy? Gonna give me four thousand for one pussy. Must be Ferrari pussy... (to McCall) How many fucks you got left, man? Enough you pay four thousand I guess. Slavi turns cancer serious.  23.

dialogues.speaker: SLAVI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The fuck you think you are? Come in here and offer money for my girl. Four thousand. Why not forty thousand? Four hundred thousand? You fucking Americans think you can come into my place of business and buy whatever you want!? You think you set the price? Fucking beautiful Russian girl... You fucking insult me. All eyes boring in on McCall. An eternity of SILENCE. The Slavi bursts out laughing.

dialogues.speaker: SLAVI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look... he almost wet his pants! I'm fucking with you, man. You got big balls coming here. I like that. Okay. Be Mr. White Knight. The fuck do I care. Slavi holds out his hand...

dialogues.speaker: SLAVI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Four thousand eight hundred for the pussy.... McCall takes it.

dialogues.speaker: SLAVI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A month. McCall goes to pull away but Slavi tightens his grip.

dialogues.speaker: SLAVI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You think one-time payment? For pussy like that? Lets go of McCall’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: SLAVI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go home and jerk off four thousand eight hundred times. Then come back. She be used up then and I sell her to you. McCall realizes that’s it. Turns towards the door.  24. Slavi nods to one of the Muscle who grabs a six-inch blad from a table and shoves it up his sleeve. Moves behind McCall as McCall reaches for the door knob. Only McCall does something unexpected... HE LOCKS IT.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL'S EYE
dialogues.text: Turns. Half-lidded. Dull. Like a alligator. WE PUSH INTO THE PUPIL AS IT DILATES. In it WE SEE...

dialogues.speaker: THE ROOM
dialogues.text: As McCall sees it. With the detachment of a predatory animal... A series of frozen pictures flashing through McCall’s hea mind calculating and evaluating a thousand details in a millisecond ...

dialogues.speaker: PARTS OF THE ROOM FADE AWAY. THE UNIMPORTANT PARTS TO
dialogues.text: MCCALL. Walls, doors, furniture, faces... Leaving only what’s necessary to him: The glass edge of a shelf. The DRAGON TATTOO covering the CAROTID on the man’ neck, the handle of a KNIFE in the man’s waistband... the throbbing heartbeat in the center of the second MAN’S CHEST... The SHOT GLASS on the edge of a table... The third man’s eye and the outline of a gun under his coat.. And the fork. Weapons and targets disconnected from any sense of humani The eye measuring the distance between the objects and th time it will take him to kill everyone in the room. This has all happened... IN THE BLINK OF... McCall's eye. MOUTH mumbling - almost inaudibly...  25.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Forty-five seconds...

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL'S HAND
dialogues.text: Moves to his watch... PUSHES a button... CLICK...

dialogues.speaker: WHAT HAPPENS NEXT
dialogues.text: Defies explanation. There is no form or elegance to it. It’s not graceful or flashy. Just brutal and beautiful at the same time. McCall snapping the glass shelf in two... the jagged edge hisses through the first man’s neck - slaying the dragon opera of blood enters the air... McCall already across the room. Planting the fork deep in the heart of the second man... The OTHERS halfway to their feet when McCall scoops the G shot glass from the table, ramming it into the eye socket the third man, driving it deep enough to enter the man’s brain... Man quivering like a frog in a science experiment... Slavi’s hand coming out of the desk drawer with a .45... McCall already pulling the trigger of the gun inside eye- socket’s pocket... Blowing Slavi’s hand off at the wrist... hand and gun twisting into the air like a dead bird... McCall catching the head of the fourth man. Using his wei and leverage to snap the neck with a nauseating crunching sound... McCall steps back... As THE MEN fall around him. Heartbeats, the rush of blood, the sigh of breath... all cease. The room now ungodly quiet.  26. McCall back to earth as gently as an autumn leaf...

dialogues.speaker: CLICK
dialogues.text: Hits the button on his watch. 49 seconds. McCall looks disappointed...

dialogues.speaker: SLAVI
dialogues.text: Gasping for breath. Hyperventilating. Handless arm aspirating blood into the carpet. Good hand fumbling with his Cell Phone... McCall crouches beside him. Takes Slavi’s Cell from his hand. Voice quiet and devoid of smugness.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Your heart's beating three times its normal rate, trying to keep your blood pressure up. That’s why you're having trouble breathing. But you’re losing too much blood. In 30 seconds your heart will give up and go into cardiac arrest. Your body’1l shut down and you’1l slowly suffocate. It’s going to suck to be you. (beat) So I need you to concentrate and listen to me... Slavi’s eyes find McCall.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want you to think about the girl. The one you beat and raped. I want you to know her life is going to go on while yours is going to end on this filthy carpet with no one giving a shit. I also want you to understand that you died over forty- eight hundred dollars. If you had taken it everything would have been different. I gave you an out but you didn’t take it. Guys like you never do. Slavi’s eyes register the last words before they go blank  27.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL'S HANDS
dialogues.text: Under a running faucet. Trickles of blood mixing with the water...

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL'S KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Dark. Silent. McCall at the sink. Cleaning his hands. Looking up at his reflection in the window. Studies it li it was some other person.

dialogues.speaker: ALARM CLOCK
dialogues.text: Hitting 5:30 AM.

dialogues.speaker: BATHROOM
dialogues.text: Empty. Mirror still steamed. KITCHEN —- MORNING Blender drying in the sink...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCall at his table. Eating his mixture when Ralphie plop down across from him. Removes his lunch. Including a can Pringles. McCall staring at them.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Test is tomorrow. You don’t want to be eating that salty sh---

dialogues.speaker: RALPHIE
dialogues.text: They’re for you. (off McCall’s look) Open it. McCall does. Nothing inside except a piece of paper with number “210” written on it. McCall looks up.

dialogues.speaker: RALPHIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What I weighed this morning. Down 9 pounds. I made the weight.  28. McCall grins.

dialogues.speaker: RALPHIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gonna ace that test tomorrow, Mr. McCall. Thanks to you. They knock knuckles. Ralphie notices the broken skin on McCall’s knuckles.

dialogues.speaker: RALPHIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: I hit it on something stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCall with the other commuters at the end of another lon day. INT. MCCALL’S APARTMENT - NIGHT McCall eating at the kitchen table. Watching the NEWS on small TV. On Screen: A REPORTER outside the After Hours Club, crime scene tape strung across the sidewalk behind her.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: ... in what Police are calling the beginning of a mob war between rival Russian factions.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL'S ALARMCLOCK
dialogues.text: Reads 2:29 AM. CAMERA PULLS BACK to REVEAL... McCall SOUND ASLEEP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scene of McCall’s decimation now empty and dark. Bodi gone but walls and floor like a Pollack canvass. THREE SHADOWY MEN IN SUITS stand center room. No one sayi anything for the longest time. Can’t see their faces.  29. But their movements are those of men of power. Not used t not knowing...

dialogues.speaker: VOICE 1
dialogues.text: No forced entry. No defensive wounds. Not one of them got their pieces out. Another long silence. A FOURTH MAN walks in. FOURTH MAN’S VOICE Security cameras in the restaurant worked fine. Till 8:02. Then they mysteriously go down for 8 minutes. 8:10 they’re back on and these guys are dead. ALL are silent. All eyes go to one man in particular.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE 1
dialogues.text: What do you want to do?

dialogues.speaker: HOME DEPOT
dialogues.text: Rolling a dolly of FIXTURES out to a Contractor’s Truck. Just another orange vest...

dialogues.speaker: BREAK ROOM
dialogues.text: McCall sitting at his table. Meal finished. No Ralphie. Looks up at the clock as one of the Fork Lift Driver’s wa past...

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Gordy. You see Ralphie? He's taking that Security Guard test after work.

dialogues.speaker: GORDY
dialogues.text: Supervisor said he called in and quit.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Quit?

dialogues.speaker: GORDY
dialogues.text: Quit. No notice. (starts off) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: GORDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Kids don’t know shit about responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A block of small family-owned places. Bodegas and restaurants manned by people who came here to get their p of the dream. McCall coming down the block checking addresses. Stops ac from...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Small place rammed mid-block. Door’s open, but the SIGN LIGHTS are off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few mismatched tables and a take-out counter. A wall in the dining area is blackened and charred from f A couple booths ruined by water damage. Two YOUNG MEN and OLDER WOMAN are working to clean up the mess. Ralphie walks out of the back room and sees McCall standi in the doorway. Face lighting up.

dialogues.speaker: RALPHIE
dialogues.text: Mr. McCall!

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Ralphie. Heard you quit. I was worried.

dialogues.speaker: RALPHIE
dialogues.text: My mom had a little accident here. Gonna have to help around here now. Turns to the older woman and tenderly motions her over.

dialogues.speaker: RALPHIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mama...esto es mi amigo, del trabajo, el Sr. McCall. El que me ha estado ayudando. (beat) This is my mother Marta. Those are my brothers Rico and Manny.  31. McCall looks around. SEES the love and hard work put into the place. Notices holes punched in the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: No one was hurt I hope.

dialogues.speaker: RALPHIE
dialogues.text: No. Happened after hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCall walks with Ralphie to the dumpster where he tosses some ruined floorboards.

dialogues.speaker: RALPHIE
dialogues.text: Probably a faulty wire or something.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Wasn’t any wire. Ralphie turns.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Point of origin was middle of the room. Aren’t any outlets there. Vent holes were punched in the ceiling. (beat) What happened, Ralphie? Ralphie gives McCall a look that could break your heart. Empties the can then turns to McCall.

dialogues.speaker: RALPHIE
dialogues.text: Lot of the people in this neighborhood are new to this country. They don’t have much except their businesses. We're easy targets. So men come in and say, for so much money every month, they’11l look out for us. Make sure nothing happens. So you pay. When business gets better, it goes up. When business is slow you still pay. You don’t... Ralphie is quiet a moment, the vestiges of defeat, loss a resignation passing over this gentle man’s face.  32.

dialogues.speaker: RALPHIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They gave my Mama a week to make it up. We’re gonna open for breakfast. See if we can make enough extra. Me and my brothers are gonna do the morning shift so my mother can rest. An odd mixture of compassion and steeliness on McCall’s f Nods his understanding that life sometimes sucks. Ralphie starts back inside.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Why don’t you call the police? Ralphie turns back. Looks at McCall with confusion.

dialogues.speaker: RALPHIE
dialogues.text: They are the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bright and peaceful Sunday. McCall approaching his Building with grocery bags in both hands. Puts them down get his keys out...

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0S)
dialogues.text: Hey! McCall turns to SEE...

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: Fresh-faced, no make-up. Walking up healed and hopeful despite the faint bruises and bandage that circles her ne McCall looks at her with surprise. Teri breaks into a smi brighter than the sun.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: Remembered you lived on this block. Been swinging by the last few days hoping to catch you. McCall drinks in the change.

dialogues.speaker: TERI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pretty different, huh.  33.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Night and day.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: Mandy told me you came to the hospital. That was nice. Not many people cared. McCall simply nods.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Well you look great.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: I’m pretty much all better. Last stitches come out next week. Other than that... Teri remembers something. Reaches in her purse and pulls a battered copy of “The Razor’s Edge.” Pause.

dialogues.speaker: TERI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ever read it?

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: Got it at a used book store. Guy there recommended it. I’m reading now. You believe that? (beat) Got a real job with real people hours. Going to open Mic Nights at a few clubs. So I won’t be coming back to the diner. (beat) A new start I guess.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: It suits you.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: Someone once told me you can be whoever you wanted to be.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Life will surprise you sometimes.  34. Teri smiles. Holds out her hand.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: I'll miss the stories.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: You have your own now. McCall reaches out and the two shake. Only Teri doesn’t l go. Childlike eyes watering a bit.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: For? And there’s a moment where we understand - she knows. Not because of any proof or certainty. She just knows... Rais onto her toes, gives McCall a peck on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: TERI
dialogues.text: For everything. Then she’s off.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Motionless. Watching her cross the street bright as a com Whole life ahead of her. When she disappears only then does McCall move. Face reflecting a strange sense of peace. Eyes understand one less person in the world is hurting. THAT HE DID THAT. Picks up his bags and heads into his building. Finally getting it. Finally understanding who he is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plastic bags cover the holes in the ceiling. A thin coat paint barely masks the burnt wall. SEVERAL FAMILIES dinin But the room is subdued.  35. Then we see why: NYPD DETECTIVES, HARRIS and GILLY occupy only booth. Large, red-faced men with predatory intent. Meals finished they slide out of the booth and stroll to register where Ralphie’s mother waits. Gilly takes a tooth pick. Ralphie’s dispirited mother removes an envelope from her apron and slides it across h counter. Harris takes it.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIS
dialogues.text: Beans were a little watery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The street is empty, traffic light this time of night. Harris and Gilly walk to their car. About to get in when.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (OS)
dialogues.text: Officers... Both men look up. McCall stands against an iron gated storefront.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: I'd like to report a crime. The Cops in no mood...

dialogues.speaker: GILLY
dialogues.text: Call 9-1-1 pal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harris behind the wheel. Flips the visor up and cranks th engine. Gilly’s CELL PHONE RINGS. Flips it open.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL, (OS)
dialogues.text: Why call 911 and unduly tax city services when I have two corrupt cops right in front of me? Harris looks out the window. SEES McCall talking to him f HIS cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cops exit the vehicle and approach McCall.  36.

dialogues.speaker: GILLY
dialogues.text: Where’d you get that number.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Wasn’t hard. (beat) Neither was getting this. Holds up the CELL PHONE so they can see the screen. A VID PLAYS. From a hidden angle. Gilly and Harris in some BODEGA...

dialogues.speaker: HARRIS, (OS)
dialogues.text: (on screen) Don’t fuck with us. Ask the lady down the street. One that had the fire last week. Could happen to you. With your whole fucking family in it. You pay like everybody else. The last IMAGE is Harris taking cash from the Proprietor. McCall closes the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: When a person obtains money, property or services from a person, entity, or institution through coercion it becomes a criminal off- Harris’ nickle-plated .38 is against McCall’s temple befo McCall can finish. Gilly grabs the Phone from McCall. Pat him down. Gilly shoves McCall against the gate.

dialogues.speaker: GILLY
dialogues.text: Copies?

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: That’s the only one. Harris and Gilly exchange looks. What kind of a fucking psycho is this?

dialogues.speaker: HARRIS
dialogues.text: You must have a death wish then. Gilly spins McCall around, pressing his face against the wall.  37.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What the fuck you want? Other than to be a corpse.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: I'd like you to return the money you took from those people. All of it. To everyone.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIS
dialogues.text: Why would we do that? McCall looks tired. The weariness of seeing too much of t shit.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Two reasons. Because I’m asking nicely. And it would be in the best interests of everyone involved.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIS
dialogues.text: Maybe our best interests are to tie a cinder block around your waist and throw you into the east River. Gilly takes out his handcuffs. Gets one around McCall's wrist... And suddenly... He's not there. Somehow now behind Gilly. Ramming his face into the brick wall. Nose hitting first. SOUND of shattering cartilage nauseating. Harris spins and pulls the trigger. Only to realize McCal thumb is already between the hammer and chamber. McCall slamming Harris hard enough with his own .38 that knocks him to his knees. Delivers several compact blows t Harris and rips the gun out of Harris’ hand. Uses it to whack Gilly across the head. Gilly tumbling like a sack o cement. Both cops down in heaps. Bleeding and dazed. McCall crouches down on their level. Adds Gilly’s revolver to hi collection.  The next words come from deep inside McCall.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: You’re supposed to stand for something. Uphold the law. Serve and protect. Justice for all. Somewhere those words lost meaning and you became everything, you used to detest. 38. McCall rises. Like a machine ejects the clips from both guns. Empties the chambers, pockets the clips and tosses guns into the cops’ laps. Battered faces look up at him.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIS
dialogues.text: Who the fuck are you?

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: The guy you didn’t count on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCall staring out the window as the STREETS and the LIFE them whiz by...

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL, (OS)
dialogues.text: By noon tomorrow you’ll have returned the money you've taken. You'll tell those people it will never happen again. Do that and this video will never be seen. INT. MCCALL’S BATHROOM McCall, ghost-like through the STEAM in the SHOWER. sorts of feelings pulsating through him...

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL, (OS)
dialogues.text: Don't and an hour later you’1l watch the uncut version of yourselves on every news outlet in the Tri-State area. All  39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pulling their bruised bodies out of their Impala. Walking towards EL TAPITO...

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL, (0S)
dialogues.text: There’s nothing you can do to prevent any of this. So don’t waste your time... (beat) I’m not like anyone you’ve dealt with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ralphie’s mother taking the brown paper bag and looking i it.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL, (OS)
dialogues.text: I'm offering you a second chance. You should take it. Shock, disbelief and joy roll across her face as she sees money and listens as Gilly explains their change of heart

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCall stocking a pallet of Garden Hoses. Looks up as Ralphie walks by, Orange Vest and work gloves on, huge sm on his face...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dirt diamond at one end of a LARGE PARK. Softball game between Home Depot and IKEA. Out-of-shape CLERKS sporting two-toned T-shirts. McCall out in left field. WHACK! The ball is smoked to left. Sailing over McCall's head who turns and takes off after it... Three steps in h pulls up, grabbing his hamstring. Watches the ball fall.. Into the glove of Young Dude 1 who comes out of nowhere l a blur.  40.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG DUDE 1
dialogues.text: Hope you're eligible for Medicaid, Mr. Pip. McCall smiles. Starts in... Then stops.

dialogues.speaker: RALPHIE
dialogues.text: Standing near the Home Depot bench. Resplendent in his bl SECURITY GUARD UNIFORM...

dialogues.speaker: INT. MCCALL'S APARTMENT- NIGHT
dialogues.text: McCall exits the bedroom. Stops at the bookcase and slide book number 93 off the shelf. "A Bend in the River" by V. Naipaul. Grabs his keys from the Foyer table and opens the front door...

dialogues.speaker: THE LARGE MAN FILLS THE DOOR FRAME
dialogues.text: Grey suit, shirt and tie. Frozen in mid-knock.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Mr. McCall. Voice soft and face with a charming, almost ever-constant smile. This is TEDDY COLEMAN. Forties, with ceramic black eyes. Body language like a walking credential. His whole being vibrates... wrong.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry to bother you. I’m investigating a homicide that occurred in Brighton Beach ‘bout 10 days ago. McCall's face gives nothing away.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Five guys dead. Russian joint.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Saw it on the news. I was there that night.  41.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: You were? McCall smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: You wouldn’t be here if I weren't. Teddy laughs.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Got me there. (beat) Just checking to see if any of the patrons remembered anything suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Actually I did.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: You did?

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: My waiter.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Your waiter?

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Would disappear for long stretches at a time. Teddy laughs.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: That accounts for the poor Zagat rating. (beat) So nothing unusual.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: None that I recall.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Okay then. About to go. Stops...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I ask why you dined at that particular restaurant?

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Felt like some Pirozhki.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Pirozhki. That’s the little pie with the onions, meat stuffed inside. Sounds good right about now. Haven’t had dinner yet. (good natured smile. Then...) I ask because there’s 7 authentic Russian restaurants within walking distance of your apartment. I assume they all serve Pirozhkis? 42. A jolt of electricity hits the air. You couldn’t tell it McCall’s face. Remains neutral.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: I was meeting a friend. She picked it.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Guess I should talk to...

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Shelly. But she won’t be any help. She never made it. Her daughter had a fever. Teddy studying the average looking McCall. Pieces sense.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Well. Thank you for your time then.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Don’t you want to give me your card? In case I remember anything later? Teddy pats his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Must’ve given them all out. not making  43. Teddy starts for the stairs...

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: How did you find me? Teddy stops.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Paid cash for my meal. Didn’t have a reservation. Wondered how you found me. Teddy’s eyes suddenly laser sharp.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: That’s what we do, Mr. McCall. Find people we need to find. McCall smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Hope you get who you’re looking for. Teddy disappearing down the stairs...

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: I always do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Idling curb side. Exhaust swirling into the air obliterat outside commotion. Teddy slides into the back seat. MASTERS turns. Teddy Jr. with matching haircut and morals but none of Teddy’s stre smarts.

dialogues.speaker: MASTERS
dialogues.text: Anything? Waits as Teddy replays the strange conversation in his he Realizes he’s not going to answer. Throws the vehicle int drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MCCALL —- FROM HIS WINDOW Watches the Suburban slip into traffic...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAY LABORERS mill by the entrance to the PARKING LOT. You Dudes wheeling out LAWN FURNITURE and GAS GRILLS as the s opens its doors...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LINDA PALISKI, the pleasant and mildly plump HUMAN RESOUR GIRL at her desk. Looks up to SEE McCall in her doorway eating a Bagel.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: You get a Bagel?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Bagel?

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Hit the lotto last night. 36 dollars. Couldn’t retire on that so figured I'd treat everyone to Montague Street Bagels.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Blueberry?

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Better hurry. McCall watches her go. Slips inside. Drops behind her des computer...

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER COMPUTER
dialogues.text: ROBERT MCCALL being typed into the search box... Teddy waits a second for the results. The LARGE ROOM he’s suggests HIGH TECH EQUIPMENT of an enormous capacity...  45.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Small room and tiny computer. EMPLOYEE FILE on screen. HIGHLIGHTS his SOCIAL and changes it. Moves to his BIRTH DATE...

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Downloads McCall’s HOME DEPOT FILE and hits PRINT. Paper spitting into the tray...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EMPLOYEES leaving for the night. McCall one of them. Bumping knuckles with Ralphie in his powder blue uniform. We’re WATCHING THIS FROM...

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE A SUBURBAN
dialogues.text: Masters, Teddy’s main guy watches McCall disappear down i the Subway. Engine running, Bluetooth connected...

dialogues.speaker: MASTERS
dialogues.text: He’s what the file says. Home Depot employee. Keeps to himself, no connections to anything we're looking for. Frustrated silence.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY, (OS)
dialogues.text: Bring it in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCall loads his basket with TRAVEL SIZE mouthwash, toothpaste, shampoo, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCall in the PC Section. Cutting, pasting then typing something on the Computer screen.  46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PRIVATE 747 sits wheels down and motionless at the end Runway 13L. Far from the terminal buildings. TSA VEHICLE crossing the TARMAC and pulling up next to th jumbo jet. Teddy Coleman is let out. Climbs the steps to the plane.

dialogues.speaker: INT. 747
dialogues.text: Stripped of everything. ALL overhead bins and seats have been removed. Just a painted, thickly carpeted cavernous shell contains nothing but four ZERO GRAVITY CHAIRS where business class would be, an aft SLEEPING SUITE and TWO COUCHES on either side of a CONFERENCE TABLE. Just outside the COCKPIT a handsome teak dining table. At which sits...

dialogues.speaker: VLADIMIR PUSHKIN
dialogues.text: Small elegant man of 33. Quietly eating dinner. Teddy gets halfway to him when A LARGE SECURITY TYPE step his way. Directs him to the conference table. IVANN GULYAYEVA motions Teddy to sit opposite him. Pushki “Advisor” clears the paper work in front of him. Looks at Teddy for several seconds. For the first time Te appears unnerved.

dialogues.speaker: IVANN
dialogues.text: Slavi Sokolov was a very valuable part of our east coast, USA enterprise. Mr. Pushkin is extremely upset at his demise. Teddy's eyes move over Ivann’s shoulder onto Pushkin. The man eats. Never looking up.

dialogues.speaker: IVANN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Eleven months ago you convinced Mr. Pushkin you and your team could offer unparalleled security and um... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: IVANN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: problem solving for our operation here. (beat) We've paid you a lot of money to shield our interests. (beat) But this happens. And now Mr. Pushkin doesn’t know what to think. Teddy looks back to Ivann. Ivann lets the words hang ther If waiting were a martial art this guy would be a grand master. Finally...

dialogues.speaker: IVANN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A man of your stature and means has neither identified or apprehended the people responsible. It sets a bad precedent. Pushkin still hasn’t looked up from his meal. As if Teddy wasn’t there.

dialogues.speaker: IVANN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr. Pushkin wants the perpetrators punished. With extreme prejudice. A clear message sent. (beat) Otherwise... Teddy feels a chill run down his spine. Looks over and SE Pushkin staring at him. Eyes milky white and dead. Pushkin may be blind but his eyes speak with impossible clarity... Fix this or I'm looking at a dead man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy and his THREE GUYS sitting in the glow of a DOZEN plasma screens. Frustrated looks all around.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Three, four guys walk into a room, I don’t care you know ‘em or not, you prepare. These were hard core killers. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not one of them gets their pieces out. No defensive wounds either. Teddy reads over the Police Report for the umpteenth time

dialogues.speaker: MASTERS
dialogues.text: Go back. What’s the motive here.

dialogues.speaker: PEDERSON
dialogues.text: Payback for the Vlastok hit... Teddy doesn’t look up.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Bunch of clowns. Company Intel had that group back in Moscow before her body hit the incinerator. Guy with the Buddy Holly glasses swivels his chair around

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Slavi handled Pushkin’s east coast trade.

dialogues.speaker: MASTERS
dialogues.text: Except no one would so much as sneeze in Slavi’s direction because of our... involvement. Teddy drops the report.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: We're looking at this wrong. We keep figuring a group. Looking at the patrons downstairs as some sort of look-out for the killing team. (beat) What if one of them WAS the killer. All eyes move to Teddy.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What if it was one guy.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: In his KITCHEN pasting the newly printed Prescription lab on the Duane Reed bottles...  49.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL'S LAPTOP
dialogues.text: Open on a TRAVEL SITE. McCall punches in his Pre-Paid Vis card number and hits PURCHASE. Confirmation for his busin class plane ticket to Cartagena, Columbia appears...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCall in the hardware aisle with a frustrated HOMEOWNER. Guy has a Home Depot bag open and is holding a Kwikset DO KNOB and DEAD BOLT package.

dialogues.speaker: HOMEOWNER
dialogues.text: +. I mean, what does it say right there?

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Universal.

dialogues.speaker: HOMEOWNER
dialogues.text: Meaning it’ll fit any existing door...

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: In the Universe.

dialogues.speaker: HOMEOWNER
dialogues.text: Only it didn’t fit in my door.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: You sure your door is from this Galaxy? The guy looks at McCall. McCall smiles. Both LAUGH.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lets get you your money back.

dialogues.speaker: HOME DEPOT, FRONT OF STORE
dialogues.text: McCall walks up front to the REGISTER AREA. Sees the LINE are not moving.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: C’mon. I’11 get you out of here. McCall walks him over to JENNY. Older and heavy set, checking out a customer on Aisle 1.  50.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jenny? Can you do a quick card refund for this gentleman? He’s in a hurry. Jenny doesn't move. Head and eyes down... McCall looks to the customer and SEES he’s WEARING A TRANSLUCENT PLASTIC MASK giving his face doll-like featur Hand in the pocket of his Hoodie griping the butt of a Ra 25

dialogues.speaker: MASKED THIEF
dialogues.text: Tell the bitch to move it, old man.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Lowers his eyes and speaks quietly.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: She's scared. I’11 get it. (beat) Excuse me, Jenny. Gently steps in front of her. Opens the cash register, ha the cash to Masked Thief. Thief about to leave when he ey the RING on Jenny’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: MASKED THIEF
dialogues.text: The ring. Jenny puts her hand over the SMALL DIAMOND RING on her ri ring finger.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: No. Please. It was my mother’s... Masked Thief pulls his weapon and cocks the hammer. Jenny bursting into quiet tears. Frantically tugging at the ring. It’s on too tight. McCall calmly takes her hand. Holds it to her cheek. Tear pool around the ring and with one twist McCall slips it o her hand. Hands it to Masked Thief.  51.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL LOOKING AT HIM
dialogues.text: Like he did the Russians: The series of snapshots flashin through in head: Gun - make and model. Mask - Price sticker with store name. Tat - peeking out of the kid’s sleeve. Car Key - hanging from his belt.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO REAL TIME
dialogues.text: McCall hasn’t moved. Stark still as the Thief backs out o the store. McCall’s eyes saying what his mouth doesn’t... Shouldn't have done that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POLICE finishing up. McCall signs his statement. Gives Jenny a pat and walks over to a despondent Ralphie.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Hey. Nothing you could do. Police just said the guy’s done four like this. Shot a Security Guard over in Bensonhurst a month ago. It’s just money...

dialogues.speaker: HARDWARE AISLE
dialogues.text: McCall passes the TOOL SECTION and a rack of sledgehammer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny punching in. Hand shaking. Bandage on her face. McC punches in behind her.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Feeling okay?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Still a little freaked out.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Need anything, I got your back. McCall walks off and WE STAY WITH Jenny.  52. Through the store with her cash drawer. To her register. Keys it open. About to slip her drawer in when she looks down in astonishment. Her mother's diamond ring laying in the tray.

dialogues.speaker: IN ANOTHER AISLE
dialogues.text: McCall walking through the TOOL SECTION. Past the sledgehammers. One missing...

dialogues.speaker: A GRAINY PICTURE OF MCCALL
dialogues.text: From the SECURITY CAMERA in the Russian Restaurant. Hardl damning until WE PULL BACK AND SEE...

dialogues.speaker: MANDY
dialogues.text: Teri’s friend from the hospital, holding the photograph. Surrounded by Teddy and his men...

dialogues.speaker: MANDY
dialogues.text: That’s him. He came to the hospital to see Teri. The Men exchange looks. Teddy takes the Photo from Mandy. Pats her shoulder as Masters drops the clear plastic bag over her head. Mandy kicks out wildly as the Large Man holds the bag tig The girl not going quietly. So Teddy jams his knife into carotid. Bag splattering with blood...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wall of windows that fronts the diner cast a dull ora glow on rain slicked street. Inside McCall’s at his table. Doorman at the counter read his newspaper. Counterman is behind the counter, changing out coffee filters. Still life by Edward Hopper.  53. The rain has the street outside quiet. A CON ED WORKER, exhausted from his shift walks up to the diner, hard hat, lunch bucket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Con Ed Guy grabs the table near the window.

dialogues.speaker: CON ED GUY
dialogues.text: Coffee. Counterman pours a cup and carries it out to the guy.

dialogues.speaker: CON ED GUY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Egg sandwich, on a roll. With cheese. Counterman back into the kitchen. McCall reading. Doorman checks the scores. Quiet. Con Ed guy stirs cream into his cup. The only SOUND is th clinking of the spoon. The CRINKLE of PAPER. Doorman folds his Daily News and leaves. Quiet. Con Ed guy sips his coffee. Yawns. Long day. McCall pours more hot water over his tea bag. Looks aroun for something. Then across the room to Con Ed Guy’s table and finds it. Bowl of sugar packets. Walks over.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Can I grab a sugar? Con Ed guy slides the bowl towards McCall. About to go ba to his coffee when his eyes catch sight of McCall’s table On it a bowl full of sugar packets. Looks up JUST AS MCCALL THROWS THE STEAMING CUP OF COFFEE HIS FACE..  54. Con Ed Guy’s SCREAM is cut off as McCall’s hand cracks th man’s windpipe. Con Ed Guy drops off his chair - Mac-10 Machine Pistol un his coat clatters to the floor. McCall looks towards the street...

dialogues.speaker: JUST AS THE WINDOWS EXPLODE IN A SHOWER OF GLASS
dialogues.text: As automatic weapon fire strafing the interior. McCall bellies to the floor. Arms pulling down tables as shields... Grabbing a table knife and JAMMING IT INTO A WALL OUTLET. A FLASH and the ELECTRICITY SHORTS OUT. Everything plunge into darkness. Except for the LASER TRACERS that dot the room followed b bullets that destroy EVERYTHING... -30 caliber shells SHREDDING WALLS, FURNITURE, GLASSWARE. every possible square inch of space.

dialogues.speaker: REAR OF THE DINER
dialogues.text: Counterman stumbles from the back confused... BULLETS dance across the COUNTER ripping up the Formica.. About to cut Counterman to shreds WHEN... McCall tackles Counterman to the floor just as... The deadly fusillade of metal SPRAYS OVER THEM. McCall laying his body over Counterman UNTIL... The shooting stops... Silence. Far off a CAR ALARM BLARES. Somewhere a BABY CRIES... The last piece of glass drops with a gentle ping.  55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIVE LARGE MEN DRESSED IN BLACK. Suppressed HK 416’s with Holographic Scopes and Thermal-mounted Screens... LASER SIGHTS dancing across every surface. Team Leader looks to 3, 4 and 5 and gestures them to the alley... Team Leader and his COHORT step into the Diner like shadows...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLACK VAN idling a half a block down from the Diner...

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE VAN
dialogues.text: TWO ARMED KILLERS sit in the front seat listening in on t RADIO COMMUNICATION. IN THE BACK GPS satellite FEEDS, MONITORS with VIDEO IMAG of the DINER and the surrounding streets... Teddy and his Three Men watch intently. Teddy leans into RADIO MIKE...

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: I’m waiting for the fucking confirmation!

dialogues.speaker: FRONT OF DINER
dialogues.text: Leader and Cohort sweep the room. Nothing but the barely breathing Con Ed Guy. Moving around the counter towards t back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCall drags Counterman and shoves him under a counter.

dialogues.speaker: BACK ALLEY
dialogues.text: 3, 4 and 5 converge on the Diner’s FIRE EXIT DOOR.  56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCall steps around BOXES of CANNED GOODS and reaches for Fire Door EXIT...

dialogues.speaker: BACK ALLEY
dialogues.text: 3, 4 and 5 on either side of the door. Guns raised... Eyes riveted to the HANDLE... SOUND OF METAL ON BRICK... 5 looks up... AIR CONDITIONING UNIT falling out of the wall and crushin his skull... 3 and 4 distracted JUST ENOUGH for...

dialogues.speaker: THE BACK DOOR
dialogues.text: To EXPLODE OPEN - McCall like the blade of a scythe. Grab before he can raise his weapon. Using his BODY as a shiel as 4 fires... Bullets hitting 3 center mass. 3's GUN going off and blow HOLES across 4’s chest.

dialogues.speaker: THE BACK ALLEY
dialogues.text: Team Leader and COHORT stepping out to find the bodies an MCCALL. Stares down the inky blackness of the Alley... Leader flicks the switch on his weapon-mounted SCREEN.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SCREEN
dialogues.text: THERMAL IMAGES sweeping across the darkness... Electrical boxes on the sides of buildings, power lines a GLOW RED AND ORANGE... ANYTHING radiating HEAT above 72 degrees appears. Further down the Alley... HEAT running along the brick an cement walls DANCE ACROSS THE SCREEN like spider veins.  57. COHORT’S POV Green tinged Night Vision. Trash and rats... The alley narrowing. No place to hide...

dialogues.speaker: TEAM LEADER
dialogues.text: Movements precise and efficient. Screen showing a BLIP. Then... HEAT IMAGE of a WARM BODY on the other side of a DUMPSTER

dialogues.speaker: ALLEY
dialogues.text: Leader positions for a clear shot. HEARS the HISSING the second he PULLS THE TRIGGER... Hollow Points blowing through the metal Dumpster. Hitting stone wall. Sparking and... Igniting the BROKEN GAS LINE... WHOOSH! Knife-like WALL OF FLAME pierces the dark alley..

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH NIGHT VISION GOGGLES
dialogues.text: FIREBALL blinding them...

dialogues.speaker: TEAM LEADER AND COHORT
dialogues.text: Ripping off goggles... McCall COMING FROM BEHIND THE FIRE... WHAM! Throats, arms tendons snapping. Bodies collapsing McCall not having broken stride as they fall... Keeps mov AS...

dialogues.speaker: STREET VAN DOORS SLIDE OPEN
dialogues.text: LAST TWO ASSASSINS jumping out...  58.

dialogues.speaker: VAN ASSASSINS
dialogues.text: Hitting the Alley on a dead run. Seeing McCall disappear around the final corner... Getting to the...

dialogues.speaker: END OF THE ALLEY
dialogues.text: Open GRATING leading under the street open and still rattling... ASSASSINS clear the opening and quickly lower themselves THROUGH THE OPENING.

dialogues.speaker: DROPPING
dialogues.text: Into COMPLETE DARKNESS below. Too inky to see anything except the GLOW of their LASER SIGHTS... They stop and LISTEN for McCall. Tasting blood... They HEAR the RUMBLE a SPLIT SECOND BEFORE... The BRIGHT LIGHT HITS THEM

dialogues.speaker: SUBWAY CAR KILLING THEM INSTANTLY AS IT ROARS BY...
dialogues.text: HOLD A BEAT after it's gone...

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: Steps out from a recessed DOORWAY IN THE SUBWAY TUNNEL. Turns and heads down the tunnel like a Ghost...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy and his Men in the middle of what’s left of the pla The SOUND of shoes on glass as they walk...

dialogues.speaker: MASTERS
dialogues.text: Who the fuck is this guy? Teddy carefully surveys the carnage.  59.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: When I was at Coronado there were stories about a disavowed team operating out of Bahrain. Reeked havoc on networks and cells in the area. Six guys with skills so off the charts it seemed like a joke. Until I met them. Then I got it. These were guys with particular expertise. (beat) They mentioned there used to be a seventh. I think we just met him. The gravity sinking in as POLICE SIRENS grow LOUDER and coming from ALL DIRECTIONS...

dialogues.speaker: MASTERS
dialogues.text: How do you want to play this? Teddy stepping over to Con Ed Guy. Picks up the Mac-10.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Bunch of Russians shooting each other over weapons, drugs... Classified investigation, need to know, blah, blah... 1I’11 handle it. Fires FOUR SHOTS into Con Ed Guy.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Make sure they’re all like him.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL'S APARTMENT
dialogues.text: Teddy and his Guys are spread out in different rooms. Surgically going through his place. Teddy standing in the LIVING ROOM studying the place like was a puzzle. Masters coming from the bathroom with empty prescriptions vials.

dialogues.speaker: MASTERS
dialogues.text: Coumadin and Precose. Pederson appearing from the kitchen with receipts from tr  60.

dialogues.speaker: PEDERSON
dialogues.text: Bunch a travel items purchased three days ago. Buddy peering over McCall’s open laptop.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Got a diabetic heart patient traveling internationally. (pointing to laptop) Bought a plane ticket to Columbia day before yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Guy was prepared for this. He’1ll have his next 10 moves worked out. That means we’re nine behind him. EXT. MCCALL’S APARTMENT BUILDING Teddy and his Men exit the walk-up and slip into their do parked Suburban.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY, (OS)
dialogues.text: Call DHS. Fill ‘emin. Call McCall a person of interest. Detain only status. Suburban pulling into traffic. WATCHING this from...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a rooftop across the street. INT. MCCALL’S APARTMENT McCall in the living room. Righting an overturned plant. Fixing the couch cushions. Opens a window to let some air in. That’s when he feels the warmth trickling down his leg. Looks at the blood pooling around his shoes. Only now realizing the he's been shot...  61.

dialogues.speaker: SHOWER
dialogues.text: Blood mixes with the water as it runs over the holes just above McCall’s hip. Entrance wound in back smallish. Exit wound ugly and jagged...

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: McCall holds a dish towel over the wounds as he removes a of honey from the stove.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE WOUNDS
dialogues.text: As McCall uses a wooden spoon to slather the boiling hone over the lesions. Cauterizing and disinfecting them. Winding gauze around his abdomen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCall on his bench. Taking in the clear but chilly night Watching faces go by. Families, kids, another world. Some internal struggle taking place. For the first time, uncertainty clouds his thinking. Eyes falling on that same shooting booth. Same father and son are back. Poor guy throwing dollar after dollar at th Barker and never coming close to winning that Sponge Bob. That’s when McCall decides. It doesn’t have to be this way... MCCALL’S APARTMENT HALLWAY McCall removes the plants on top of the bookcase. Reaches inside the top shelf and WE HEAR a CLICK... McCall slides the bookcase to the left. The entire unit rolling away to reveal...

dialogues.speaker: A SAFE ROOM
dialogues.text: The keeper of secrets. Devoid of anything except the bags and boxes of a life on upon a time that sit untouched on the floor.  62. A built-in shelving unit contains a few items we recogniz The car keys from Home Depot Thief. Handcuffs from one of Ralphie’s corrupt cops. Teri’s CD... And the bloodied cell phone he took from Slavi.

dialogues.speaker: BLACKBERRY SCREEN
dialogues.text: List of phone numbers SCROLLS BY. One particular number occurring more often than the others.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL'S KITCHEN
dialogues.text: McCall dialing the number. RINGS once and WE HEAR...

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY, (OS)
dialogues.text: You've reached my cell. Leave a message or call my office at 212- 246-7614. McCall jots the number down. Dials it. After THREE RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY, (OS)
dialogues.text: Agent Coleman’s office. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I was trying to reach someone else. Can you transfer me back to operator? Two more RINGS and a FEMALE VOICE...

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR, (OS)
dialogues.text: Central Intelligence Agency. How may I direct your call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Classic beaus arts decor, the night sky ceiling, the ston and ironwork never looked more ominous. CROWDS of people rushing to and from trains. McCall one of them. Disappearing into the tunnel of TRACK 17...  63.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rolling meadows defined by old, split rail fences and far dating back to the birth of this country. Great shadows o clouds blanket the green hillsides. A nondescript RENTAL CAR winds its way across the Valley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rental car rolls up a two-rut excuse for a driveway i the middle of nowhere heading towards a modest, farm hous Late 1800s, beautifully maintained. A screen door swings open and JASON PLUMMER steps onto th porch. Early 70s with serious, deep blue eyes that have seen mos what life can offer. Good and bad. Wears soft, comfortabl clothes and a smile that matches. Watches as McCall gets out. The two stare at each other f a long moment. McCall walks up to the porch stairs. No words are spoken. But we feel something significant here as they walk insid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCall, Plummer and his wife SUSAN sit at an old plank ta Lace table cloth, aged flatware and china, garden picked flowers. The three eat in comfortable silence. No one feeling the need to ruin the meal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCall washing. Plummer drying. Susan brings in the empty serving trays. Exchanges looks with her husband then walk out for the rest.

dialogues.speaker: PLUMMER
dialogues.text: Stopped counting the reasons I married that woman years ago.  64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well-worn early Native American. Pendleton blankets and throws. Fire going. McCall settled into a chair next to i Plummer cracks walnuts on the couch. Susan comes in with a tray of drinks. Sets it down on the slab of redwood that stands in for a coffee table. Hands McCall a cup of hot water and the exact tea bag we've see him use at the diner. After a beat of silence Plummer stands.

dialogues.speaker: PLUMMER
dialogues.text: Well. I’11 leave you two to catch up. Susan waits for the door to close. After a moment...

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: If you’ve come for my help I can’t give you any. I have no influence these days. I fly to DC three days a week. Sit in a office reserved for people with secrets too scary to let completely out of sight. I think they're afraid I’m going to write a book or something. Apparently that’s what retired spooks do out here. If McCall hears her he doesn’t let on. Finally takes his eyes from the fireplace. Looks at Susan...

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: What would the CIA have to do with a bunch of Russian pimps? Susan processes the statement. Her answer comes quickly.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Nothing. The CIA doesn’t care about pimps. Russian or otherwise. So start with the fact they weren’t pimps. Selling girls was a hobby. Susan waits for McCall to process this.  65.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Think Amazon. Big. All encompassing. Sells everything. Place an order it’s delivered to your doorstep. Items are shipped to you from various warehouses across the country. (beat) Amazon employs teams to run those hubs. (beat) The Russians - specifically, Vladamir Pushkin - are the black market Amazon. Gasoline, weapons, drugs, bonds, executions, extortion, secrets, you name it they provide it. Pushkin considers the US the biggest shopping mall in the world. (beat) You took out Pushkin’s East Coast team. Shut down a hub. Your CIA friends were paid to protect that from happening. Now they’re looking for blood. (beat) More tea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rolling hills likes waves on a black sea. A long rail fence that disappears into the horizon. McCal and Susan leaning against it. Silhouetted by the cobalt night sky and lit by an old Coleman lantern. A long moment.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: When they told me you were dead, I didn’t believe it. Not from something as trivial as an IED. It just wasn’t you, Robert. (beat) That you're alive is a relief. But not a surprise. Jason and I talked a great deal about you over the years. If anyone could have figured a way out. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A way to walk away for good, start fresh... it would have been you. (beat) Either way I figured I'd never see you again. Preferred it that way. I imagined you wandering the earth searching for some peace, some understanding of yourself. Wondering if you’d find it in time. Lantern FLAME flickers in McCall’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In all my years as a handler there was no one ever like you. Your skills were undefinable. A mind that saw things no one else did. In ways no one else could. (beat) What you did for your country cannot be measured. You saved lives too many to count. Yet it didn’t feel good to you. Even though what we did mattered, it didn’t feel right to you.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: I couldn’t see...

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: The meaning. I know... Flame starting to die out.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The greatest violins cannot hear music. The most beautiful paintings cannot see the joy they bring. It’s simply the way it is. (beat) We can't all be heroes, Robert. Someone has to sit on the curb and clap as they go by. A LONG silence.

dialogues.speaker: MCCALL
dialogues.text: I didn’t have to go there. I didn’t have to kill them.  67.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Yes you did. McCall looks at Susan.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
